This game is probably my favorite strategy game since the old Command & Conquer games. There's an absurd amount of content, even without buying any DLCs (which you should only buy on sale since they go on heavy sale several times a year - same goes for the base game). If you own the first or second game (and/or their DLCs), you can play all those factions in this game and they don't feel just shoehorned in at all. Every campaign feels different, even if you play the same faction twice. There are lots of great difficulty settings and a very active mod community. Lots of stuff to do on every turn and it feels very rewarding to learn how the world and intricate politics of the different factions work, and to leverage game systems to your advantage. Your faction leader, race/faction mechanics, start position, political standing, and most of all your actions every turn have a huge impact on how the campaign will play out, and there are 200+ factions on the map that also impact everything. The map is also huge (if you are playing on Immortal Empires, which you should be as soon as you've learned the game basics), you could be 100 turns deep and just about to conquer your entire continent, meanwhile on the other side of the map, some faction you haven't even encountered has gotten even bigger than you. 

Sound design and music is good, graphics are good, UI is mostly good but not perfect. Achievements are pretty fun to go for with the exception of the trials of Tzeentch ones, those are such a slog (but at least not that hard). 

The game is also great to play with a friend, you can play any campaign alongside a friend who is playing another campaign in the same world. You could be on other sides of the world, fighting back to back, or going against each other, and it makes politics even more interesting because your allies and enemies probably won't line up with your friend's.  

The game runs well, but load times are really bad if you use a hard drive or an old SSD, so save yourself a lot of time and use a new-ish SSD if you have that option. There are some bugs, but I would be shocked if there were no bugs in a game where this much stuff happens every turn. The game-breaking bugs do get patched out by the devs usually pretty quickly, which unfortunately happens instead of them developing new content. CA's PR team is horrendous and Sega has a skeleton crew working on the game for some reason (seems really weird since this is CA's biggest source of revenue) so meaningful content updates come out less and less frequently, and often with delays. I'm sure this is the main reason this game is getting review-bombed right now, which is pretty valid, but I wanted to put my review here because even though the current trajectory of the game's future looks pretty bad, the game as it is is great, no if ands or buts. I too am unhappy with the bad PR and lack of work going into content updates, but I have almost 1000 hours between this game and Warhammer 2, and could easily milk out a few hundred more with just what is currently available, and that's without addressing mods, of which there are many that add quite a lot of high-quality content.

If you like Warhammer, I feel pretty confident in saying this game is richer in lore than any other Warhammer game, and it interested me enough to get me into the tabletop game and other video games. The lore is very interesting and the world always feels coherent. Most campaigns end up feeling like you're roleplaying a character or telling a story of your own making within the rich world of Warhammer fantasy. 

Overall, this game is just really good and provides a bevy of highly varied experiences. If you like complex strategy games and feeling like you're building a fantasy empire, you'll love this game. I hope CA gets its stuff together and gets more people working on the game's updates, but I doubt that will happen, but even though that makes me sad I'm still glad the game exists and is as fun as it is.

Do not be dissuaded by the negative reviews. There is literally no other game that compares. If you like Total War strategy and Tolkienesque D&D-like fantasy, you should remove all doubt and just dive right in. Whatever the shortcomings of Creative Assembly, they've made the world and all its characters come to life in a remarkable way, with great animations and outstanding voice casting. 

What I highly recommend you do, however, is to play it with Venris's SFO: Grimhammer III and Hecleas AI Overhaul mods. They will greatly improve the length and challenge of your campaigns, combined with whatever QoL mods to suit your fancy. There are literally hundreds of mods that pick up the ball where CA dropped it or that add additional content.

I warn you though, that, if you get into it, you may have to pull out your purse more often than you expected, not because the game has micro-transactions, but because there are over a 100 unique Legendary Lords / factions to play with (and more to come), many whom will need to be unlocked by purchasing their respective game (Warhammer I or II) or DLC they came with. But even without them, you'll have many options to get you going for hundreds of hours. You will have access to 10 or 12 factions if you only buy Warhammer 3. 

People can complain about the price tag, and since Warhammer III, it's not without reason. Warhammer 1 & 2 offered DLCs which added 2 new factions for 7,49â‚¬; Warhammer 3's DLCs generally offered 3 new factions for 25â‚¬, now 23â‚¬, a steep incline. Although you can choose to pay only for one faction at a third of the price. 

But even if I have spent approximately 440 bucks in total on all the games + DLCs since 2016 (you should be able to get all for less than half of that during sales), it's given me over 5,000 hours of game time. Even at full price, that's more than 12 hours of return per euro / dollar spent. Where else can you get a full day of fun for 1 euro?

Ever seen a T-Rex fight a Black Dragon? A giant War Mammoth vs a Treeman? An army of undead against a dwarven shieldwall? Ever marched through Chaos-infested wastelands filled with devils and demons with a bunch of spearmen and bear riders? 

No? Then what are you waiting for?

When the overwhelming majority of the reviews are not about the game but essentially about a series of youtube dramas and PR, it can be difficult to sort the quality of a game from the online discourse.  The game itself?  Good.  The people who have played 1000 hours and have nothing but bad things to say?  Comical, if a bit embarrassing.

If you've enjoyed Total War in the past and want it to be more bonkers, you might be interested.  If you like the setting and want to simulate a campaign in Warhammer Fantasy, you might be interested.  If you are looking at the dozens of DLC and offended that you have the option to pay more for more content: take a deep breath.  Understand that none of them are required and each can provide you with dozens of hours of playtime if you like it.  Find a faction or lord that appeals to you and pick that one up.  Only buy one at a time--there is no value in a DLC you don't play.  The base game has a variety of factions and lords that will keep you going for a good long time.  If you don't find fun there, you don't need to worry about the DLC.

Oh, and play Immortal Empires.  The base scenario is the less fun option.

Have a nice time.  There's nothing quite like this game on the market.

Total War: Warhammer III is fantastic. I could write everything I love about this game, but I will let the 1000+ hours I have invested speak for me.

This is a great game. I may be slightly biased as a long time fan of both the Total War series and the Warhammer Fantasy tabletop game, so combining the two was a win-win for me. 

Beyond that though, with all the DLC they have made for this and the various iterations of this game that have been released, it never feels stale or old. The fact they keep updating and releasing new content of course helps as well. 

Now, occasionally an update can bring with it some issues. Recently, the AI for several races got wonky and would not function properly. While annoying and somewhat breaking game immersion, it by no means made the game unplayable.

In fact, for such a large game with so much content, map and in game area, there are quite few "bugs" that I've even noticed - between all three total war Warhammer releases I think I am over 4000 hours now and not once have I had to restart or quit a game because of a "bug."

Again, may be a little biased, but this is one of my favorite total war games and would recommend this to anyone that is a total war, strategy battle game, or Warhammer fan.

The Great: The amount of raw content and time you can spend in this game is amazing. I've been a long to 4x game and a long time RTS player and the union of the two of them here makes for a very exciting time.

The Good: Graphics, music, animations - all of the presentation here is on point. I've seen monsters from the tabletop that I've said "I wonder how this will look in game?" and every time it looks better than what I can imagine. There are some graphical errors, your camera sometimes falls through the map but it comes nowhere even close to eclipsing how visually impressive this series is.

The Less Good: I'm not aware of the all the drama around CA. Weird DLC schedules, treating their best content producers very oddly, not finishing that South bit of Cathay. None of this really bothers me, but this community is quite vocal when something is less than excellent.

The Bad: The learning curve here is atrocious. The AI acts in a bewildering fashion on both the Campaign map and in the battles. The game is *expensive* as well, there are so many DLC's. Don't get this unless it's on sale.

All in all I'm nearing in 1k hours and I've only played about 40 of the Lords in the game. The sheer dollar to time value I've achieved here is nothing short of wonderful. Thanks for reading!

Couple things to address. First the DLC. The DLC does not lock you out of actual gameplay mechanics or parts of the map. Every unpurchased lord or race is available to play against so you see them on the map when you play them. The base game has plenty of races. How this game works is if you buy 3, you have access to the immortal empires, which is the huge campaign with every single race involved, however you are limited to play as only the factions in immortal empires. If you buy 1 and/or 2 you have access to the factions in those games. Then you can buy the DLC for factions and Lords for factions you find are interesting. It looks like a lot, but genuinely just buy the DLC for the faction you think looks the coolest. You don't have to buy it all at once, so don't let that complete package price daunt you. 

Secondly, there's a lot of drama with the company and youtubers. Creative Assembly is a greedy video game company, simple as that, and there's a popular total war youtuber who basically quit because of them. They also tend to do things like have bugs that come out while they ship DLC that doesn't work. Welcome to gaming in 2025 unfortunately. 

Barring those two things, this game is an absolute gem and if you are remotely interested in warhammer or strategy games I highly recommend giving this game a shot.

This is one of those games where I wish steam reviews weren't just a simple Yes or No recommendation.

At its core, TW:Warhammer III is a good game that stands out from games in other Total War series due to its variety and uniqueness of factions, units, and playstyles. Even if you're not into the Warhammer franchise, you can enjoy this game if you're into strategy, big battles, and fantasy. The sound is good, the visuals are good, the voice acting is great. The battles can be very entertaining.

I like the game, I really do. However, I just can't RECOMMEND buying the game for people new to the series.

Let's get this out of the way first. The DLC situation with this game is particularly egregious. Even if you paid full price for this game, you only get a fraction of the factions unlocked. And even those unlocked factions in the base game aren't fully unlocked, portions of it, legendary lords (which determine your starting point and playstyle) and even some upper tier units, are locked behind DLC. The DLCs combined for Warhammer III can cost you way more than twice as much as the base game. But let's say you like the game, you decide to buy all the DLCs for the WH3... and yet, you still don't have everything unlocked. Why? Because not only do you need to buy all the DLCS for WH3, [u]you need to buy Warhammer 1 AND Warhammer 2 AND all their respective DLCs in order unlock everything[/u]. In addition, they don't support cross platform, so if you have WH2 on epic and WH3 on steam, guess what? You gotta rebuy WH2 on steam just to unlock the stuff for WH3.

But let's say you're mister/missus money bags and you don't mind spending a couple hundred dollars to unlock things in the game. There are many minor (not game crashing) bugs and bad design choices that aren't terrible on their own but are horrible when they all come together. Not all factions are equal, and understandably so, as it's difficult to perfectly balance a game around all these factions and legendary lords that can completely change how you play a faction, but those are not the bad design choices I'm talking about. For example, in the previous games, minor settlements can gain walls if you built the correct building and upgraded it. Certain factions were unable to do this but gained other advantages to make up for their lack of walls. In WH3, they've completely done away with gaining walls in minor settlements for every faction without making up for it. As another design choice, they've nerfed the garrisons defending your settlements. By design, the AI, to compensate for not playing as smart as a human, gets more resources and have less upkeep, which allows them to field more armies than you (and the higher the difficulty, the more resources and less upkeep). This results in the AI generally being in more places and able to just steamroll your minor settlements, regardless of your defensive buildings, if you don't have an army babysitting it (and most factions can't support having an army babysitting every settlement). In the previous games, the walls forced them to siege your minor settlements buying you time to get an army over to save the settlement, but in WH3, it's like playing Whack a Mole with all their armies running around going for your undefended bits, which quickly gets very tedious. It wouldn't even be so bad if your major walled settlements were choke points or something, but no, the AI just waltzes on by. Just a bunch of bad design choices coming together to make a horrible (and very common) situation.

There's also all these weird (but not game crashing) bugs that just ruin things sometimes. The more commonly noticeable one is when the AI gathers several armies around a town and... just sits there doing nothing (for possibly the entire game). And this is a VERY common occurrence. The other more commonly noticeable (well, if you play with a faction with ranged units) is that sometimes your ranged units just stop firing at will. They'll shoot if you manually tell them to attack a target but that defeats the purpose of firing at will. They could have clear line of sight to the target, no obstacles, on a flat plain, with ammo, in range, and they just won't fire at will. This makes things particularly unpleasant if you're playing a range heavy faction and downright cost you some battles if you're in a big battle and you don't notice your ranged units doing absolutely nothing because you were busy micromanaging another part of the battle. Even melee units will have brain farts at times where you order them to engage/chase an enemy unit and they just walk in and stare while the enemy is busy whacking away at them or just follow (and not attack) the enemy that's running away even though your unit is faster and should be cutting them down while running.

I could go on but this review is long enough as it is. I like the game but I just can't quite recommend it buying it especially if you're new to the series. I understand companies need to make money, but it just doesn't feel like the value is worth how much they're charging. Some people can argue that just the base game alone is worth it but you definitely feel the difference when you play a base game faction and find out some of your unit roster is locked behind DLC. And if you're expecting people to spend hundreds of dollars, at least try to keep it as bug free as possible.

Before the qualities (or lack thereof) of this videogame can even be discussed, it is important to bring up the cost. I am writing this on the evening of the 25th of November, 2025; in a little over a week, on the 4th of December, the next DLC "Tides of Torment" will be released. To access everything in this game, you need to buy [b]3 STILL RETAIL PRICE games[/b] (that are 9, 7, and 3 years old respectively), for a total of $179.97. When Tides of Torment releases on the 4th of December, Warhammer III will breach the $500 threshold, coming in at [u]$526.16[/u]. I will list off several things that come to mind, however there are more valid complaints than can be typed in a reasonable amount of time.

[h3]Terrible AI[/h3]
This is primarily a single player game (I will touch on multiplayer aspects later), most of your time will be spent engaging with AI opponents of two different flavors. The [b]Battle AI[/b] is absolutely feckless. On offense it forms a long single line and runs straight at you with no regard to the terrain, nor their opponents or their own army composition. This results in it forming giant blobs of its own units which are easily blasted into paste with ranged fire and spells. On defense it forms a long single line and sits there doing nothing until the player either weighs a flank (which causes the AI to pivot its whole force), or it takes enough damage from projectiles of any variety to cause it to flip into its offense mode detailed above. The [b]Campaign AI[/b] is absolutely craven. It spends its time sitting in walled settlements, sitting on units it recruited in the first 5 turns of the campaign because it can't disband them. It does this until it is in a state of war, where it decides to actively avoid enemy armies on the field, and go hit undefended, unwalled, minor settlements instead. It will only ever engage in a pitched battle if it perceives the autoresolve value to be in their favor before the armies actually make contact (the AI doesn't have fog of war and can see everything that isn't in ambush stance at all times, so it doesn't need any reconnaissance). The only time you will ever face it on the field is if you bait it with an ambush, or it has formed a big blob of armies and is moving them all together.

[h3]Cramped Campaign Map[/h3]
Despite being "the biggest Total War map ever", the Immortal Empires map (the only singleplayer mode anyone will play, I am not even going to discuss Realms of Chaos in this review) is so [b]condensed[/b] that it doesn't feel very big at all. Unless you are in a Jungle biome (which lowers armies movement by default), most settlements in the game are only 1 turn of movement away from each other. If you combine the AI's craven, avoidant behavior with the density of settlements, it results in [b]the[/b] problem that everyone complains about more than anything else.

[h3]Sieges[/h3]
The siege battle situation in this game is unacceptable. The frequency of these sieges are caused by the reasons I listed above. This wouldn't be as much of an issue if this battle type was actually fun; but the battle AI's passivity plus its terrible pathfinding, settlement layouts, stupid building and capture point mechanics, and bugs (primarily with the gatehouses and getting on and off wall segments) do everything in their power to make that not the case. The other problem is that the player is on offense 95% of these battles because the cowardly AI refuses to attack the player's hardpoints unless they have 4 stacks rolling together. I don't think that the solution to this problem is "remove sieges" as so many like to say, I think CA needs to take a hard look at Total War: Shogun II, and Total War: Medieval II, and use those two game's sieges as a baseline to build from.

[h2]Multiplayer[/h2]
Despite the singleplayer focus of the game, it [i]has[/i] multiplayer. On paper, a game like this should be a wonderful multiplayer experience, but once again there is a factor in play to prevent this from being the case. The main issue is the [b]complete lack of servers[/b]. All of the connections in this game are done peer to peer, and as a result whenever ping is involved, the game quickly turns into [i]Warhammer III the interactive slideshow[/i]. The way the game handles latency hasn't changed since [b]Total War: Rome from 2004[/b], it [i]sloooooows[/i] down, and depending on how bad the latency is, it will just stop.

[h3]Multiplayer Campaigns[/h3]
You can do multiplayer campaigns, which could be fun if you aren't playing with somebody from another country, or somebody who has poor quality internet. The more players you add to one of these campaigns (it goes up to 8) the worse it gets, as everybody is directly connecting to each other, rather than a server to sync the gamestate. In the previous titles, the maximum was 2 players in a multiplayer campaign, so the additional players is cool in theory. They also made it to where you can do your turns simultaneously, which is awesome until two players go to war with each other, and then it becomes a frantic clicking match as a [b]TURN BASED CAMPAIGN MAP[/b] goes realtime.

[h3]Competitive Multiplayer[/h3]
This community is split in 3 ways. The first split is between those who use the games built in matchmaking, and those who join insular Discord communities based around the tournament scene. The second split is between those Discord communities, between the newer Domination game mode, and the traditional land battle game mode (which is now doing Conquest mode instead). There is no siege battle focused community like there was in the heyday of Medieval II, this is because siege battles are terrible. The same latency problems are in play here, and on top of that now you're picking to play with either: automatch scumbags who spend their time abusing the lack of rules, or Discord eSports people who want to regulate you to death.

[h1]Summary[/h1]
If you don't have ANY of this games content, don't buy in. If you disregard that advice, buy in on sale. I am stuck in the sunk cost fallacy, be warned.

For full transparency, I have played Total War games at least since Shogun 2, and went back to play Rome I (best Total War) and Medieval 2 afterwards: They are cornerstones of my taste in games; which makes reviewing this game that much harder.

Total Warhammer 3 is an uneven offering, with many glaring errors, lackluster mechanics and outright atrocious player freedom. For every neat thing in the game, two to three basic failures pop up. It gets to a point, where you wonder how a studio with so many years of notes from prior games to learn from could keep falling over themselves.

I originally intended to include the Realm of Chaos campaign into the review, but realized quickly in doing so that the main appeal of the game is Immortal Empires, so I will be focusing on that.

Key points:

The voice acting, map stylization from the lore and general presentation is outstanding. It is frankly one of the best realizations of the Fantasy setting I have ever seen, brimming with life and character. From the small things, such as flavored tech and character traits, to the grand stylings of the factions and their visual details. Looking at the factions, their units and the game itself is a visual feast. The sound must also be mentioned. Though there are shortcomings, especially from old content that is legacy from TWW1, the sound design broadly brings the warhammer setting to life, especially with its use of audio cues that makes busy battles easier to parse. There is also a world of magical items, which add a level of flavor that would have been entirely acceptable to see the studio cheap out on, but they did not, and deserve props for their inclusion.

What I cannot be so glowing on is everything else.

The map looks like ass. Instead of an easily parsible map, or an ability to simplify the terrain and give commands, TWW insists upon itself; you will look at its spanning, pointless eyesores and baubles when you just want to move a unit from one mountain range to the next, it's a genuine eyesore to keep track of units on the map.

Then again, you won't be keeping track of many units at a time, becaue Total Warhammer insists on using Rome 2 as its skeleton, meaning you only get to have units run around with generals, who will emerge from nowhere, with no family trees to speak of; which works for some factions, but for human and elven factions, is absolutely ridiculous. It heavily deincentivizes building smaller units and moving them around the map, because anything short of a full stack of units is going to be chowed down by a 20-stack ai unit and its 4 companion stacks coming out of the mist (looking at you, Vampire Counts).

Despite the studios' "best efforts" to bring legacy factions into the newer games with revised mechanics and improved gameplay experiences, they still come up painfully short. The Empire, the face of the series, has a pathetic tech "tree", which rivals Bretonnia for brief but painfully bad. Comparing these to newer factions is genuinely an effort in futility.

And these tech trees are shared amongst factions, which makes for an even worse experience. To alleviate this, each lord has a faction mechanic, which are supposed to individualize them, and in that matter, some of them are excellent: Balthasar Gelt is a fan favorite for a reason, and his colleges mechanic is a lot of fun; but then you have him go to the Empire, and you end up having to fight Nuln and Reikland to unit the EMPIRE, because Gelt doesn't get the mechanic that allows him to interact with the Prestige system; or Bordeleuax, a faction who starts flanked by the newer (see: better) faction Skulltaker with no rites to help his expansion, forcing a turtle playstyle to build up the numbers to auto resolve him to death.

On that note, auto resolve is thoroughly confused. It has never been great, but it is frankly baffling how it's supposed to take things into account, with factions such as Beastmen and Slaanesh always getting the short end of the stick, yet in battles, they rip units to shreds. It gets to the point, where in particularly annoying sessions, I have resorted to stacking trash armies to stack the auto resolve in my favor; a strategy which is near unbeatable, with the exception of the likes of the Skaven and Beastmen, who can ambush you with attacks (and ambushes are extremely fair and balanced, with units running away the moment the enemy makes contact :D) 

Battles are not that much better, with thoroughly confusing statistics like Anti-large, which counts against cavalry, but doesn't actually do well against cavalry, unless it has armour piercing, because armour is the king of stats in the game; especially in Auto-Resolve (hello Dwarves; hate you). Though it is a visual feast to see Imperial gunners rain hell on an enemy, it is thoroughly annoying to play, because the AI will do utterly foolish moves, like archers attempting to go past the defensive line to get closer to an enemy well within range (With bows, mind), or archers turning 30 degrees to the right to hit a unit on the right side of their vision cones; you can't even see the accuracy of units, with some units supposedly having poor accuracy, but nailing an opposing, accurate artillery battery with pinpoint precision. This, coupled with the ATTROCIOUS MORALE SYSTEM, which devolves into running your general in circles to keep your troops in the fight, or having your troops surround your fleeing general, it makes for an extremely unintuitive experience, and makes TWW one of the worst battle experiences in the series.

Most obvious shortcoming in battles however, is the utter lack of decent music. I have tried to find good tracks for this game; it is beyond my grasp on how you can go from Rome, Medieval and Shogun 2 to TWW, where no track stands out to me. The trailer music is more memorable, and it's not even in the game.

The game is, to be quite honest, massive, and there is a bunch of stuff I could mention, such as the map just ending in an ugly, glaringly empty world, or how the game is thoroughly unstable, requiring an SSD to even run at any acceptable rate, but any actual issues, mechanically, visually or gameplay wise, is usually (And sadly) forgiven by the fanbase at large, because no one else delivers the same style of games. The core issue at large, is that even this mediocre experience is consistently knee-capped by Creative Assembly, and their inept QA, stubborn HR, and INFLEXIBLE core team, who think themselves above us mere peasants, who dare play their darlings without their consent (talking about the game is a privilege, not a right).

For more than a decade, they have been doing the routine "we messed up; we're sorry, here's some mediocre content (you need to pay for) to make up for it". It took a youtuber calling them out (and a month's wait time) to resolve basic issues, like the AI sitting on their ass around their castles, not doing anything, whilst some AI's, such as the ogres, Beastmen, Lizardmen and Tomb Kings just decided to stop working. All the while, they want to charge INSANE prices for the same tech tree you burned through before, but this time, the reskinned hero with a different mount and one (1) unique line of powers can do something the other ones in their faction can do, but slightly better! Truly, what would we do without these ground breaking visionaries.

Even with such obvious antagonism, it would be forgivable, if the studio wasn't riding high off their own farts, whilst bullying anyone that steps out of line, to the point of studio whistleblowers having to come out to speak up on how bad the internal state of the studio is, how they actively reuse assets to sell back to the community to keep up their one (1) source of consistent income. They are so reliant on this game's DLC, they (according to rumors) cancelled internal game projects over the failure of Shadows of Change DLC.

TL;DR: Game's mediocre and the studio is cringe. Don't recommend.
